facts.text: Petitions under article 32 of the Constitution raise a common question whether section 5(7A) of the Indian Income-tax Act is ultra vires articles 14 and 19(1)(g).

anchor.surface_text: BHAGWATI, J. - These petitions under article 32 of the Constitution raise a companymon question of law whether section 5  7A  of the Indian Income-tax Act, hereinafter called the Act, is ultra vires the Constitution as infringing the fundamental rights enshrined in article 14 and article 19  1   g .

facts.text: Petitioners in Nos. 97 and 97A of 1956 are Messrs. Pannalal Binjraj, oil mill owners, merchants and commission agents at Sahibganj, branch at 94 Lower Chitpur Road Calcutta; Petitioner No.1 and R.B. Jamuna Das Chowdhury karta of HUF.

anchor.surface_text: The facts which led to the filing of the petitions may be shortly stated. Petitions Nos. 97 and 97A of 1956 The petitioners and Messrs. Pannalal Binjraj, oil mill owners, merchants and companymission agents, carrying on business at Sahibganj in the district of Santhal Parganas, having their branch at 94, Lower Chitpur Road, Calcutta, petitioner No. 1, and R. B. Jamuna Das Chowdhury, resident of the same place and erstwhile Karta of the Hindu undivided family, which carried on business in the name and style of Messrs. Pannalal Binjraj, Petitioner No. 2.

facts.text: Before 28th September 1954, petitioners Nos. 97/97A assessed by Income-tax Officer, Special Circle, Patna.

anchor.surface_text: Before 28th September, 1954, they were being assessed by the Income-tax Officer, Special Circle, Patna.

facts.text: On 28th September 1954, Central Board of Revenue transferred cases of petitioners Nos. 97/97A to Income-tax Officer, Central Circle XI, Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: On 28th September, 1954, the Central Board of Revenue made an order transferring their cases to the Income-tax Officer, Central Circle XI, Calcutta.

facts.text: On 22nd January 1955, Central Board of Revenue transferred cases of petitioner No. 2 to Income-tax Officer, Central Circle VI, Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: On 22nd January, 1955, the Central Board of Revenue transferred the cases of petitioner No. 2 to the Income-tax Officer, Central Circle VI, Delhi,

facts.text: On 12th July 1955, Central Board of Revenue transferred cases of petitioner No. 1 to Income-tax Officer, Central Circle VI, Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: and on 12th July, 1955, it similarly transferred the cases of petitioner No. 1 to the same officer. After the dates of such transfer to the Income-tax Officer, Central Circle VI, Delhi,

facts.text: Petitioner in Petition No. 44 of 1956 is Shri A. L. Sud, sole proprietor of Messrs. Amritlal Sud Construction, resided in Calcutta since 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner in Petition No. 44 of 1956 is Shri A. L. Sud, the sole proprietor of Messrs. Amritlal Sud  Construction  who originally belonged to Hoshiarpur district in the State of Punjab but has since 1948 been residing and carrying on business in Calcutta.

facts.text: Prior to 29th June 1955, Shri A. L. Sud assessed by Income-tax Officer, Special Survey Circle VII, Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: Prior to 29th June, 1955, he had been assessed to income-tax by the Income-tax Officer, Special Survey Circle VII, Calcutta.

facts.text: On 29th June 1955, Central Board of Revenue transferred case of Shri A. L. Sud to Income-tax Officer, Special Circle, Ambala.

anchor.surface_text: On 29th June, 1955, the Central Board of Revenue transferred his cast to the Income-tax Officer, Special Circle, Ambala, and the said officer companytinued the proceedings in the transferred case and also instituted further proceedings against the petitioner

facts.text: Petition No. 85 of 1956 filed by Messrs. Bhagwan Das Sud Sons, merchants, Hoshiarpur; case transferred by Commissioner of Income-tax to ITO Special Circle Ambala.

anchor.surface_text: Petition No. 85 of 1956 was filed by Messrs. Bhagwan Das sud Sons, merchants, Hoshiarpur, but on that date their case was transferred under section 5  7A  of the Act by the Commissioner of Income-tax Officer, Special Circle, Ambala.

facts.text: Shri A. L. Sud is member of HUF Messrs. Bhagwan Das Sud Sons.

anchor.surface_text: Shri A. L. Sud, the petitioner in petition No. 44 of 1956, is a member of the Hindu undivided family carrying on business in the name and style of Messrs. Bhagwan Das Sud Sons

facts.text: Petitioners in Amritsar group (86,87,88,111,112,158 of 1956): family members directors of Hindustan Embroidery Mills Pvt Ltd at Chheharta near Amritsar; cases transferred on or about June 29 1953 from ITO A Ward Amritsar to ITO Special Circle Amritsar.

anchor.surface_text: These petitions may be companypendiously described as the Amritsar group. Amritsar, to the Income-tax Officer, Special Circle, Amritsar.

facts.text: Nandram Agarwalla sole proprietor of Sriram Jhabarmull, business at Kalimpong and Calcutta branch; cases transferred multiple times, key order 27th July 1946 by Commissioner Central Calcutta under s.5(7A) to ITO Central Circle IV Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: These petitions companycern the assessment of the petitioner to income-tax for the respective years 1944-45... on 27th July, 1946, orders were passed by the Commissioner of Income-tax, Central, Calcutta, under section 5  7A  transferring the cases of the petitioner to the Income-tax Officer, Central Circle, IV, Calcutta.

facts.text: Kalloor Siddanna of Raichur group (225-229/1956), commission agent; cases transferred 21st December 1953 by CIT Hyderabad from Addl ITO Raichur to ITO Special Circle Hyderabad; later ~May 1955 back to main ITO Raichur.

anchor.surface_text: On 21st December, 1953, however, the Commissioner of Income-tax, Hyderabad, issued a numberification under section 5  7A  ordering that the case of the petitioner should be transferred from the Additional Income-tax Officer, Raichur, to the Income-tax Officer, Special Circle, Hyderabad... shortly before 19th May, 1955, the Commissioner of Income-tax, Hyderabad, made another order under section 5  7A

facts.text: Section 5(7A) inserted by Indian Income-tax Amendment Act 1940 (XL of 1940) following Bombay HC decision in Dayaldas Kushiram v. CIT.

anchor.surface_text: This sub-section was inserted by section 3 of the Indian Income-tax Amendment Act, 1940  XL of 1940  which was passed as a result of the decision of the Bombay High Court in Dayaldas Kushiram v. Commissioner of Income-tax,  Central .

facts.text: Explanation to s.5(7A) added by Indian Income-tax Amendment Act 1956 (XXVI of 1956) following SC decision in Bidi Supply Co. v. Union of India.

anchor.surface_text: By the Indian Income-tax Amendment Act, 1956  XXVI of 1956 , an explanation was added to section 5  7A  in the terms following as a result of the decision of this Court in Bidi Supply Co. v. The Union of India and Others

facts.text: In Bidi Supply Co. v. Union of India, SC did not decide constitutionality of s.5(7A), held omnibus order invalid.

anchor.surface_text: This Court, by a majority judgment... did number adjudicate upon that question... It is enough for the purpose of this case to say that the omnibus order made in this case is number companytemplated pr sanctioned by sub-section  7A  of section 5

facts.text: Court holds s.5(7A) intra vires, not violative of art 14 or 19(1)(g).

anchor.surface_text: It follows, therefore, that section 5  7A  of the Act is number violative of article 14 of the Constitution and also does number impose any unreasonable restriction of the fundamental right

issues.text: Whether section 5(7A) of the Indian Income-tax Act is ultra vires the Constitution as infringing the fundamental rights enshrined in article 14 and article 19(1)(g)

anchor.surface_text: These petitions under article 32 of the Constitution raise a common question of law whether section 5  7A  of the Indian Income-tax Act, hereinafter called the Act, is ultra vires the Constitution as infringing the fundamental rights enshrined in article 14 and article 19  1   g

issues.text: Whether section 64(1) and (2) of the Act confer a valuable absolute right on the assessee to be assessed locally

anchor.surface_text: The argument on behalf of the petitioners is that section 64, subsections  1  and  2 , of the Act confer upon the assessee a valuable right and he is entitled to tell the taxing authorities that he shall not be called upon to attend at different places
